paragraphs.text: But in the third and final year, things were different. The psychiatrist didn’t know it. His job, like those of most men who have given up, was to get people to agree with him or get rid of them.
paragraphs.name: 9c0d

paragraphs.text: “The blatant insincerity of the way I was treated troubled me very much. I didn’t yet understand that people used celebrities as figures of fantasy; they didn’t want to know who you really were, any more than kids at Disneyland want Mickey Mouse to pull off his rubber head and reveal that he’s just a local teenager. The kids want to see Mickey. And the doctors in the cafeteria wanted to see Young Dr. Hollywood. And that was what they saw.” — Michael Crichton, Travels
paragraphs.name: a8a9

paragraphs.text: If we want to build a better world, the story behind the story of the men and women who escape the collective violence must be spread far and wide.
paragraphs.name: e6e4

paragraphs.text: There is no better feeling (or ambition) than tearing back the curtain and exposing false relationships.
paragraphs.name: a47e

paragraphs.text: The boy was smart, but the crowd was relentless. In school, the boy was taught that the way to escape was through a societally worshipped career track — medicine. With nowhere else to go, the boy trusted his educators, and became good at getting good grades. And he earned his way into the most prestigious place for those good at getting good grades — Harvard.
paragraphs.name: 75d6

paragraphs.text: When posting on social media, you can be tolerant of improper use of the English language. When writing for and about writers; you really need to be using proper terms and spelling; “they’ll” isn’t even a word. “We’re are” is totally redundant. Forgive me, but I just can’t get past that kind of sloppy use of language. That said, I otherwise enjoyed the article.
